snippet: Voters in the blue-collar Seattle suburb of SeaTac will soon decide whether to raise the local minimum wage to $15 from $9.19 an hour, a move that could have profound implications.
abstract: Voters in Seatac, Wash, will soon decide whether to push the local minimum wage to $15, an increase from the state's $9.19 minimum hourly wage, which is the highest in the nation; business and labor leaders say the economic and political implications of a raise in the minimum wage could be profound, with local democracy going where state and federal legislators mostly fear to tread.

byline.original: By KIRK JOHNSON and STEVEN GREENHOUSE

lead_paragraph: Voters in the blue-collar Seattle suburb of SeaTac will soon decide whether to raise the local minimum wage to $15 from $9.19 an hour, a move that could have profound implications.

headline.main: In Washington State, Home of Highest Minimum Wage, a City Aims Higher
headline.print_headline: In Washington State, Home of Highest Minimum Wage, a City Aims Higher
